qas.question: In what direction does the San Diego River run through the city?
What bodies of water can be found separating different developed areas of the city?
What is created by the many canyons and hills throughout San Diego?

answers.text: small pockets of natural open space

qas.question: What divides the city's northern and southern segments?
Where did the San Diego River once flow to?
In what direction does the San Francisco River run through the city?
What bodies of water can't be found separating different developed areas of the city?

plausible_answers.text: small pockets of natural open space

qas.question: What is created by the many canyons and hills throughout San Francisco?
What divides the city's eastern and western segments?
Where did the San Francisco River once flow to?

context: The city lies on approximately 200 deep canyons and hills separating its mesas, creating <a2_0><b7_0>small pockets of natural open space<b7_0/><a2_0/> scattered throughout the city and giving it a hilly geography. Traditionally, San Diegans have built their homes and businesses on the mesas, while leaving the urban canyons relatively wild. Thus, the canyons give parts of the city a segmented feel, creating gaps between otherwise proximate neighborhoods and contributing to a low-density, car-centered environment. <b8_0>The <a3_0>San Diego River<b8_0/><a3_0/> runs through the middle of San Diego from <a0_0><b5_0>east to west<b5_0/><a0_0/>, creating a river valley which serves to divide the city into northern and southern segments. The river used to flow into <a4_0><b9_0>San Diego Bay<b9_0/><a4_0/> and its fresh water was the focus of the earliest Spanish explorers.[citation needed] Several <a1_0><b6_0>reservoirs<b6_0/><a1_0/> and Mission Trails Regional Park also lie between and separate developed areas of the city.
